WRITING.TEXT: I enjoyed the story. I think it's an interesting take on what the future could end up looking like. gt;She died in an aircar accident six months ago. This sentence allows the reader to infer that the story is taking place in the future. Since aircars do not exist (at least not yet) it's a smart way to set yourself up for later in the story when it's important to know it's in the future. gt;Life insurance dispatched me this morning. I do not like the way this sentence is worded. Saying life insurance dispatched something doesn't really make much sense. Life insurance is not a concrete noun; it's an abstract noun. Because of this, it can not act on its own to dispatch something. Only a concrete noun could dispatch something and be able to act with a verb. Therefore, the sentence should be something like this: gt;The life insurance agency dispatched me this morning. gt; gt;The life insurance company dispatched me this morning. gt; gt;Her life insurance policy was enacted dispatching me this morning. The only way I could see the original sentence being correct would be if life insurance is a synecdoche, but there would be no way for the reader to know this. gt;I found her son watching cartoons. gt; gt;Our boy is so smart. These two sentences don't work well together. You change the perspective which confuses the reader. Does the clone think the boy is her son? Or does she think the boy is not hers? There is not a way for the reader to figure this out because of the change in perspective. I just wanted to focus on the more technical aspects of the story rather than the story itself since it seems most of it has been thoroughly covered already.

WRITING.TITLE: [112] Crash Landing
WRITING.TEXT: [My Critique](https://www.reddit.com/r/DestructiveReaders/comments/cu6pr3/150_mom/) \*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* #8220;YOU ARE NOW ENTERING THE ATMOSPHERE, #8221; blares a robotic voice through the pod #8217;s communication system. The woman comforts her whimpering child, #8220;We #8217;re almost there sweetie. Everything will be alright. #8221; They crash. The radio crackles, #8220;Why did you launch the emergency pod?! #8221; blurts a panicked voice. #8220;The ground is still not survivable. You #8217;ll be dead within days! #8221; #8220;I had no choice, #8221; the woman replies, #8220;I saw the oxygen generators were in critical failure. We only had hours left. #8221; Pausing for a moment the voice responds, #8220;You weren #8217;t supposed to see that. #8221; Another pause, #8220;There was a glitch. Everyone will be fine. #8221; The pod #8217;s battery then dies leaving them in utter darkness and silence.
